subject: Critical Thinking
title: The Euthyphro Dilemma: Does God Decide What's Good?
description: A 60-second lesson on The Euthyphro Dilemma: Does God Decide What's Good?.

hook.text: Plato asked: Is something good because God commands it? Or does God command it because it's good?

buildup.text: Horn 1: if good = whatever God says, then God could command torture and it would be good. Morality becomes arbitrary.

discovery.text: Horn 2: if God commands things because they're already good, then goodness exists independently of God.

twist.text: This 2,400-year-old dilemma still applies to any authority-based ethics: 'It's right because the law says so.' Same.

climax.text: The lesson: morality can't be grounded solely in authority.

punchline.text: If 'good' just means 'whatever the authority says,' then nothing is truly good.

quiz.question: What does the Euthyphro dilemma challenge?
options: The idea that morality can be grounded solely in divine or authoritative command
